story: Those who take men into battle are either saviors or tormentors depending on their ability to lead.
Brave souls who plunge fearlessly into battle\nare fools with no regard for the value of life.
Those who consider cowardice in battle a strength\nare wise souls who understand the importance of life.

Scream. Demand. Desire.
Covet like no one is judging.
Confess the will to survive,
for survivors are the true victors.
Page 1\nI'm really scared,\nbut I can handle it.
Page 2\nI've left much undone,\nand this will be my record of regret.

Page 14
・I wish to tell them how I really feel.
・I wish to make my parents proud.
・I wish to do work that brings people joy.

Page 101
It hurtsIT HURTSit hurts I'm scared! Why me?
Why do I have to kill him?Killthemall
Ahahahah! Just give me life!Killthemall
Deathdeathdeathdeathjust give me time!
Kill one, and you're a murderer. Kill them all, and you're a hero. There once was a man who wished this weren't the case.
He swore to never kill. To never be a hero.\nBut nobody on the battlefield believed him.
He refused the nature of war.\nHe would face a million arrows if necessary.
The man's wish reached the heavens.\nThe clouds parted and a staff of light landed between the two armies.\nAll who felt its power threw down their weapons and hung their heads.
The magician's raison d'être was simple—love.\nHe would sacrifice everything for the woman he loved.
So he sacrificed all the nation's people to the corpse of his wife... Friends and siblings alike.
The man's wish would be granted...\nBut only when he offered his own soul to the corpse did his wife return to the land of the living.

Once revived, the woman realized there were numerous souls within her.
Not knowing who was responsible,
she immediately released the souls to their rightful owners.
In the end, all of the man's efforts
only ended with his own death.
The man gave up everything that mattered to him.\nThere was nothing more he could do.
Stab. Pierce. Penetrate.\nThe man sought the power to protect his princess from any threat. To that end, he sacrificed his voice to his beloved sword...\nThe voice that his princess loved so dearly.

Cherry blossoms whirled with blood and gore on the rain-drenched battlefield. The man thought about the words he could no longer say. He had dedicated them all to his sword.\n"I came so close to love," he thought.\nBut even that had to go unsaid.

His voiceless screams roared across the battlefield
as he gently held the lifeless body of his princess.
"Here rests the silent swordsman's beloved."
He could only tell her how he truly felt through the epitaph he wrote on her grave.
In order to live, we consume countless lives.\nEveryone does it. And we keep doing it without a second thought. But for me, at least, it's something special...
I'll eat again today.\nBut as time went on, I felt less and less comfortable about the lives I had taken. At times, I had to force back the urge to throw up.
We found ourselves lost in a secluded land.\nIt was barren, without plants or animals. Without vegetable or meat.
A little food and my shipwrecked family was all that remained.\n"Mother, thank you for the feast," I said, as I gently lifted the last remaining spoonful to my mouth.

The elite guards. The most powerful military force between two neighboring countries.\nThat was his calling. But no matter how many friends he had, his loneliness never ceased.\nIf friendship meant deceiving each other to get to the top, he would be better off alone.

While on duty, he met a woman that shared his disdain for their homeland. She would become his savior, their marriage freeing him from the loneliness that he so feared.\n"How can I keep the peace, when I'm always on the run?"\nSpurred by this thought, he took his wife and fled the country.

Their family grew to three. The man soon forgot his fear of loneliness, but she remembered the extravagance of her old life every anniversary when they exchanged handmade presents... All they could afford. Still, she supported him no matter what hardship befell them.\n"As long as I have you," she said.

His wife was with child, and the family learned they would soon be four. Or so they believed. Palace guards loomed in their doorway.\nThe man fell in a pool of his own accursed blood. A traitor, taking a bullet had ever been his fate for abducting the princess.\nIn death, he condemned his wife to the same loneliness he so feared.
The boy ran wild. He was angry. He always lashed out.\nBefore long, no one could blame him.\nThe boy stole and stole. One day, he ended up with a sickle rumored to cause hallucinations.
As he continued to use the sickle, he came across a man he couldn't overpower. The man was a hero who had made his mark on history.

"Remember this always. My swordsmanship is second to none. My skills are beyond what you could ever hope to achieve." The man bowed his head, his breathing as calm as ever. The boy hated losing. He lashed out again, channeling his anger in hopes of becoming a stronger fighter.

The boy grew stronger and stronger, until he was strong enough to get his revenge.\nBut just when the boy's sickle struck the hero, the hero disappeared—he was nothing more than an illusion.\nHaving trained himself into a hero to face the man, the boy had ultimately become his successor.
There once was a harp created by a slothful god.\nIt would grant any languid desire to the user for 30 days\nin exchange for their libido.
One day, a lazy womanizer came across the harp.\nHe played it, putting everyone around him to sleep,\neven himself and all the pretty girls he spent his nights with.
He used its power to manipulate others into doing his work for him while he slept the day away. All his girlfriends were left to their own devices.
After the 30 days, his desires went unfulfilled, but the harp's power had vanished.\nHe had asked for eternal slumber,\nand all the pretty girls were more than willing to grant him that wish.
An inquisitive girl read a tome and began to contemplate suicide. What would be the most beautiful way to die?\nThe ugliest?
What would be the happiest way to die?\nWhat would be the cruelest?

To be strangled to death with the entrails of your beloved.
To have your head crushed under the foot of an elephant.
To have all of your fingers, toes, and eyelids cut off, and die from exhaustion.
To be confined to a room of mosquitoes and die slowly from blood loss.
It was a tome of death, containing all the ways people have died.\nThe inquisitive girl read the tome again.\nShe contemplated suicide.
◆My book on the pursuit of happiness◆\nAll I have to do is pray! So easy!\nI'll do it again tonight!
◆My book on the pursuit of happiness◆\nI can be happy just by putting a vase here!\nSo strange! So convenient!
◆My book on the pursuit of happiness◆\nThe gods are all-powerful! I'll worship all of them!\nObey all of their commandments! So interesting!

◆My book on the pursuit of happiness◆
In time, I'll find true enlightenment!
Happiness is the precept that restricts this body!
To find more happiness, I'll join more religions. So faithful!
I'm hungry.\nI just want sweets.\nI want "free money" to eat all the candy I want.
I want to play house.\nI don't want to do my chores.\nI want "free time" to play all I want.
I don't want to see anyone.\nDaddy doesn't want to see the people he works with, either.\nI want "freedom" to be alone.
Eternal darkness. A world of infinitely spreading darkness. I won't be hungry. I won't be busy. Nobody will get in my way. Darkness... A world of freedom as far as the eye can see.
Thump, thump. Thump, thump. That throbbing...\nThe thing I wanted most.\nHis most important place.
He refused me many times. But I got over it. Got over him. Besides, I got everything I wanted in the end.\nI got all of him.
I felt his warm heart in my hand, my own heart leaping with joy. Was it wrong of me to take it by force?\nHis body went cold soon after.

I did everything I could.
I loved him every night, hoping his warmth would return.
Was my love not enough?
His heart stank and fell apart.
There once was a frail man who found a strange hammer on an old battlefield. When he swung the hammer, the man sent powerful tremors through the ground. His frailty was no more.

The man trained with the hammer day and night, until entire nations feared him. As he crushed enemy after enemy, the man noticed that those he killed appeared in his dreams. During the day, they would whisper malicious words into his ears.

With the voices gnawing at his soul, he cut off his ears so as not to hear them. But the malice continued to echo through his brain.\nThere was no escape.\nTo finally escape his suffering, he gave his hammer to an apprentice and ordered him to smash his master's head in.

But his apprentice, with a heart far weaker than the man's, succumbed to the malice immediately and died. Fearing their fate, nobody else laid a finger on the hammer, and the man who only wished for death's sweet release lived the rest of his days in agony.
Once, there was an elf that liked to tell tall tales.\nBut they were so unbelievable that everyone who heard them would leave.
One day, the elf met a human woman who enjoyed listening to him. She would let him talk and talk for ages.\nShe would occasionally interject to show she was still listening, but he didn't mind.
Once the two were wed, the elf came to a startling realization—his wife was deaf. This continued happily for another hundred years.

The elf knew that his wife had long since passed,\nbut he still found himself talking to her. It was the only thing that kept him going. When the last of her corpse had finally rotted away,\nthe elf went insane and followed his conversation partner into the abyss.
I like to rumble, it makes my body sway.\nI like whirlpools that turn anger into praise.
Cries for justice make my body sway.\nThe roar of battle cannot be drowned.\nI live for this.
The flow of blood makes my body sway.\nMy master fought the enemy's justice.
At times of peace, my spear yearns for another confrontation.

There once was a strange bird that captivated the king with its beautiful voice.\n"That bird would make a wonderful harp," the king thought.\nThe next morning, he promised a huge sum of money to a pair of blacksmith brothers in exchange for the instrument.

The older brother was lazy, but the younger was diligent.\nDespite this difference, they were as close as could be. The promise of a huge reward, however, was more than enough to create a rift between them, and the younger brother finished the task as the older slept.

The younger brother proudly displayed the bird's corpse.\nWithout a moment's thought, the older brother, blinded by greed, thrust a kitchen knife into his younger brother. To hide his guilt, the older brother blamed the younger's death on the bird and left to see the king.

The harp was eventually finished, and the king was eager to hear it.
The harp began to sing.
"The elder brother's heart is coarse, he killed the younger without remorse."
The king understood and had the older brother beheaded.

Faced with a predicament, a wizard turned to a forbidden tome...
But he was too late.
The boy had entered into a contract with the tome
without consulting anyone first.
Rule 1. Never hesitate.\nRule 2. Never give up.\nRule 3. Never rest.

Rule. Rule. Rule...
RuleRuleRuleRuleRuleRule
Rule. Rule. Rule. Rule. Rule. Rule.
RulesRulesRules and more Rules...

All the way up to 1,000...
Rules. Rule. Rule. Rule. Rule. Rules...
These are the rules to be followed by he who seeks my power.
"Death" is all that awaits.

Gafia (f.1087) "Rise to Action Speech I"
No matter how sound the argument, the enemy will not listen.
No matter how loud we shout, our message of justice is lost on them.
This is unlike anything we've ever faced.
Gafia (f.1087) "Rise to Action Speech I"\nSo we will negotiate through our common language—violence.\nMay victory go to the just!

Gafia (f.1087) "Rise to Action Speech II"
If a king is someone who protects his people, then I suppose I'm not a king.
But I am the same man I was before I was crowned,
and you swore an oath to me, did you not?

Gafia (f.1087) "Rise to Action Speech II"
Brave citizens of Gorval!
The time has come to shed blood in another reckless affair!
Let us partake of the sweet wine of victory!
"I know you. We've never met...but I know you."\nA willowy voice spoke from inside my head.\nAh, yes. I remember where I had heard this voice before.

My first mission.
Before I knew it, I had found myself in the deepest depths of a forbidden dungeon.
I knew I shouldn't touch the monument,
but I couldn't help myself.
My fingers...outstretched...\nWhat I saw when they touched it was...amazing.\nA familiar place, but of which I had no memory.
My nemesis' hand in mine...\nDefinitely the future. It was a prophetic dream. A future that could not be changed.\nIt gave me goosebumps.
Sorry. I'm not returning the hostage and I'm going to kill you. You're okay with that, right? You'll have the rest of your afterlife to be together.
Who said I was going to play by the rules?\nMaybe you should wise up a bit.\nThen again, you'll never get that chance.
Liar. Traitor. Deceiver. Fake. Wicked. Underhanded.\nDeluded. Shallow. Cheater. Coward.\nCall me what you will. It matters not.
A coward. That's what hides deep inside my heart.\nA coward. The sword in the dark that fights for its life.
I am your follower.\nI am but your loyal weapon.
I am your follower.\nIf you order it, and they still breathe,\nI will not hesitate.
I am your follower.\nIf you order it, I will kill both old and young in equal number.
"...Understood."\nFollowing the hammer's order, the man painted his master in blood.
"No matter where you go, I'll follow."\nHe worried about her. She was always moving between jobs. So he moved too.
"No matter the hardship, I'll help you."\nHe drove away every suspicious-looking man who tried to approach her.
"I'll give my life for you, if you so desire."\nHe gave her gifts to show the depth of his emotions.

The man was captivated by his own devotion.\nShe couldn't understand his feelings.\nBut when he was sent off to war, he shouted, "I swear on my bow, we'll meet again!"...It shook the woman he loved to her very core.

There once was a girl who didn't believe in her village's customs. She wouldn't join their rituals, and sometimes, would even try to stop them. The other villagers shunned her for her strange ways. She knew, of course, that she being so different meant she must be crazy, which also meant she's never change.

The village would have to be the one to change. She was sure they would. With that hope in her heart, she continued to disrupt the village's rituals. Then one day, her constant meddling turned the village against her father, the only family she knew.\n"I must stop causing trouble," she thought, and decided to change.
But no matter how she tried, her ideals would not waver. Just then, she had an epiphany.\n"I really can't change the world, can I? I'll just have to change myself."

So the girl participated in the village's coming-of-age ceremony. She killed an elder villager with her bare hands and ate from the corpse. Tears flowed from her eyes, and vomit from her lips as she completed the ritual.\nWhile her moral compass no longer guided her, she was relieved that the village finally accepted her.
The man was a poet, and he was up to no good.
His power of speech had become a magical one.

With just one word, even the most defiant would become obedient. It brought him immense joy to steal their freedom. He would whisper bitter shames into their ears, and watch them break down in front of him.
The man turned their confessions into poetry.\nHidden truths became embarrassing songs.\nHe loved spreading others' secrets.
Chapter 1: Shell Box\nAn object that uses "time fragments" to give people the "power to travel through time." A person with a shell box embedded in their brain is called a "time citizen."
Chapter 2: Shell Box\nThose who become time citizens are resigned to having their memories meddled with by "History's Protectors." If the shell box is removed, they die.
Chapter 3: Shell Box\nA black box is used as an intermediary to ensure that historical modifications made by time citizens are part of the "chronological record."
Chapter 4: Shell Box\n"History's Protectors" 403 Error (Access Forbidden)
The king was the only person that mattered to the entire country. The people believed that no one else deserved respect.
After his death, they looked to his symbol—his staff—for guidance.
From time to time, someone raised his staff.\nNobody would oppose the will of those who did.
If the wielder of the staff was filled with greed and chose to become a dictator, the people were sure to fall in line.
Despite being held by both just and unjust alike,\nthe sword had nothing to do with good or evil.\nIt simply echoed the feelings of its owner and granted them power.

So when a boy who sought harmony came into possession of the sword, the world was all but certain to be at peace.\nBut because the sword had a twin, he couldn't help but wonder what would happen if the other object fell into the wrong hands.
The war between good and evil continued...\nUntil history took an unexpected turn.\nIt occurred to the boy that, for good to exist, the world needed evil.

So the boy defeated all evil, and hammered the twin swords into one. From then on, he dedicated his life to keeping a precarious balance between good and evil, allowing both to prosper but neither to triumph.
There once was an old man whom the world wished to bless. The world tried to plant seeds of joy in his life, but none of them ever seemed to take root.
The world brought forth a demon for the old man to defeat, but much to everyone's surprise, this had little effect on the old man's life.

After defeating the demon, the old man went for a picnic in the mountains. He didn't bat an eye when the wind played a prank on him, scattering his food in the air. He bested a bear in a test of strength before lunch. That evening, he found the largest turnip he'd ever seen in his field. He plucked it from the earth with a single hand.

His life continued to be filled with good fortune for years to come. Eventually, the world stopped interfering in the old man's life.\nIt was only then that accounts of his heroism spread far and wide.

"I'll be a farmer. My father protected this small plantation with his life. It's not in the best location, and it doesn't even produce much...but I've played here since I was young and still see it as home. My brother left for the city, so it fell to me to look after it."

Sorry. I'm counting on you.
I always thought I'd go to the city and return to the village as a great doctor.
But it's too late now...
I've been trying to leave for ages.
However...leaving your home is harder than it seems.

The two brothers walked slowly toward the edge of town.
"Well, maybe in the next life."
They hugged as if for the last time.
Just then, the ground shook as a large army appeared
on the expanse of land before them.

The brothers roared and screamed with all their might,
running headlong to their deaths in the hopes of saving even just one villager.
They were outnumbered 1000 to 1.
They knew how the battle would end.
Nevertheless, the brothers stood their ground, facing the army that rushed toward them with the force of a tsunami.
What's wrong? Why are you crying?\nYou can tell me. I'm a friend of the weak.\nI'll grant you anything you wish.
What? How cruel a parent can be!\nWould you like a present?\nOr maybe, you could listen to what I have to say instead.
Okay, it's a promise. Leave the window unlocked before you go to bed.\nIf you don't, I won't be able to give you your present.
What's wrong? Why are you crying?\nWhat's wrong? Isn't this what you wanted?\nI only did as you asked. You said you wanted Daddy to disappear, after all...

A winged man came to another filled with regret.
"You made a choice," the winged man said. "Now you want to undo that choice. To erase that memory. Erase your regret."
The man responded without hesitation.
He regretted a promise he had made to his wife.

The man was forced to dedicate his life to his wife.
He went so far as to give up his career as a musician.
That was his promise to her.
But having given up his passion, he lost interest in life, and succumbed to regret.

The man begged the winged one over and over again to undo his choice, but the winged figure wasn't able to give the man the life he wanted. The man could only come to one conclusion—all his suffering was because he was born in the wrong place and time.

"Fool. People like you give up on life without even trying.
You all want the same thing."
But having incessantly pleaded with the winged man,
the devil finally took the man's soul in exchange for a violin.
Melt away. Melt away. Melt away the night's darkness...\nAnd fall. Fall. Fall into the abyss of my heart...
I want to spew all of my wicked emotions into this book. If I do, he's sure to see me as pure.
Do sweet nothings not make me feel ill?\nDoes desire not make me anxious? If so, why discriminate? I'll expel all of my feelings for him onto these pages.
All of the emotions I've written about him have turned the pages black.\nThis book contains nothing but madness. Insanity in its purest form.
◯Guild Hub/Tavern (Night)\nApprentice\n"It shouldn't have taken me so long to collect the herbs. That was supposed to be an easy task."
◯Guild Hub/Tavern (Night)\nGuild Master\n"Don't be silly." Even the most seasoned veterans make mistakes. "Everybody has to start somewhere."
◯Guild Hub/Tavern (Night)\nGuild Master\n"Don't get me wrong. Your fighting prowess isn't the reason you're in this guild."
◯Forest/On the way home\nGuild Master\n"Everybody has high expectations of you. You'll make a fine mage. We'll have each others' backs in battle."

Long ago, there were two brothers whose strength was known far and wide. They heard rumors of a treasure that could help them save their sick mother, and so they put together a crew and traveled to a cave in hopes of finding it.

Many trials awaited them.\nOne after another, their companions died. Only the two brothers managed to make it to the deepest depths of the cave and find the treasure.\nFull of hope, they opened the chest. While skilled, they were new to adventuring and didn't take the proper precautions before opening it...

The older brother suddenly burst out in laughter.
By the time the younger brother realized something was wrong, it was already too late.
He shook his older brother violently, but the laughter continued.
The younger brother smelled a stench coming from within the chest, and ran away in terror.

In his hasty retreat, the younger brother slipped and fell in some mud.\nThe next thing he knew, his hand was drenched in blood. His life was over.\nIt's been said that he now haunts the cave as a ghost, warning adventurers "not to open the treasure chest inside."
To be desired, to be lusted after, to be forced upon...\nTo be used like an old rag.
No warmth. No cold. Just apathy.\nOver and over again...
Being forced to do disturbing things.\nOr brutally forced to do things that go against my nature.
That's why I closed off my heart...\nWhy I swore an oath to live life as my master's tool.\nAn oath to give in to brutality.

The meat was too perfect.
Probably made by someone with similar taste to my own.
The skilled eye of someone that shared my profession.
Jealousy overtook me faster than the electric currents surging through my brain.
Annoyed. Annoyed. Annoyed...\nI was just plain annoyed.\nThat's why I sought a weapon that I could use to hone my skills.
No matter how good the weapon, no matter how hard I trained, perfection continued to elude me.\nNo matter how many I killed, I never again tasted meat like I tasted that day.

I understood immediately. The man who stood before me created that meat.
Squish. Squash... Squish. Squash. Squash. Squash.
"So, so beautiful..."
The next thing she knew, she had been turned into the meat she sought.
Nobody knows what wish was made upon the bow.\nBut the chain of hatred it left in its wake has led to such massive conflicts that it's become known as the Calamitous Bow.

Since it was intended for the announcement of ceasefires, it was created with the ability to shoot impossible distances.\n"Let's put an end to this foolish war. It all started from a single misunderstanding. There's no need for all this bloodshed."\nThe bow was made to accommodate the desire for peace.

The day finally came where the bow saw its first battle.\nIt had been watching over the battle.\nThe arrow it fired went farther than imagined. Not only farther, but faster and higher, and well into the battlefield.

"The terms for peace will be delivered soon.
The soldiers probably won't agree, but a peaceful world is..."
The Death God's arrow fell upon whomever desired peace the most.
The enemy's prime minister removed the arrow from his wife's head. Consumed with hatred, he condemned this cowardly act and ordered his army to leave no man alive.
The jaws are blades that let no prey escape.
The scales are shields that will never shatter.
The eyes show conviction that cannot be broken.
When taken in hand, the scythe steals the wielder's humanity, forcing them to give up everything to receive the power of the dragon.

The woman was beyond lucky.
She got everything she wanted in life,
and knew for certain fortune smiled upon her.
After all, she had chanced upon a magical tool.
There was no wish it would not grant.

The scales granted the woman's wishes without demanding compensation.\nShe thought it strange that, with every wish, the scale would begin to tilt her way,\nbut her concerns vanished as her wealth expanded.

One day, on a whim, she decided to wish for everything.
The scale tilted far to her side, as if granting her wish.
The scale fell heavily to one side, and the woman was
run down by a passing carriage and killed.

She never learned the truth.\nThe scales simply granted an advanced payment on a person's life, and that's what it had been giving her.\nAs such, she never questioned her own fate even after it had run its course.
I  want  to  love  him,  to  be  loved by him,  to  become  one with him.
I  want  to  be  with  him  now  and  forever.
I  want  to  be  drowned  and  devoured  and  mixed  with  him.
I  want  to  be  swallowed  by  his  joy  and  his  pain.

"Hey, let's hang out. You'll want to hear this."\nHe was a bad influence, and his face told me all I needed to know. I wasn't going to want to hear this. "You know the big house up on the hill? They say that the family left the grandfather there and disappeared." It wasn't the first time I'd heard of a "rich" family leaving in the night to escape debt. It was pretty common.

My friend's plan was this...\nThat evening, we would sneak into the house and take whatever of value was left. With only an old man living there, he figured the house would be free for the taking. "Ugh." That's all I could think as I became a part of his scheme. Still, we had plenty of experience with petty thievery, so we both had faith that we'd be fast enough to get away.

When evening came, we snuck into the house through the window. We didn't even need to pick the lock like we'd planned. I wrote it off as the carelessness of the elderly, but something about it left me uneasy.\nAs we walked around the house, we saw no signs of neglect. If anything, it looked well cared for.

We found an archive as big as a library and started going through the bookshelves. That's when it happened. There was a sudden "boom." When I ran to the bookshelf where my friend had been, all I found was a single book.\nTerrified, I left the house without stealing anything.\nThat was two weeks ago, and still, my friend is missing.

There once was a woman who sought revenge above all else. Another woman had stolen her family, her status, and even the man she loved...\nHer mind was made up. She'd take everything from the other woman, including her life.\nBut she wouldn't just kill her; no, only the most painful death would do.

In time, the woman got her revenge by sealing the subject of her wrath in a staff. This ensured a long, painful death. After all, the other woman was a sorceress.\nLosing all of her magic would be pain beyond reckoning.

So she channeled the other woman's magic through the staff, using it in countless battles.
She gleefully vanquished enemy after enemy.
In time, her and her staff gained great renown.
Unfortunately, she died before achieving her ultimate goal.

At the moment of her death, she swore she'd heard the staff whisper, "I win."\nOn the day of her funeral, her family mistook the staff for something precious and buried her with it. Forced to spend the afterlife with her mortal enemy, the woman knew greater torment than her enemy ever would.

There will be nothing here before long.\nOur world is slowly being consumed by darkness.\nThese are our final moments. His face consumed my heart. I could almost cry. His face... A smile only I was allowed to see.
I was fine, though...\nFine being swallowed into the eternally expanding darkness. As long as it was with him.\nI was even happy about it...
No matter how hard I reach, that day will not return to me. But if that's how it has to be...
Eventually, after much resistance, the world accepted me. The fake world that he made... A warped place. I reached out once more, hoping to say one last thing...

In an empire of steam, there once was a man who accomplished missions like a machine.\nHe followed every order to the letter.\nAfter a single insurrection, his fortitude earned him a promotion to leader of the Oracle Knights.

The man had neither selfish desires nor feelings.
His past was spent on the battlefield,
forging him into a loyal minion of the state.
His devotion was steadfast and he obeyed every order.
And so, the state trusted him to handle their darker matters.
The man had neither a past nor emotions.\nStill, nightmares plagued him every night. The state had killed the person he wanted to protect the most, and now they haunted his dreams.

The man sowed seeds and waited for them to grow.\nHe looked forward to smelling the sweet scent of his blossoming revenge.\nWhen he bowed his head to the king, his eyes burned with the fury of a warrior.
<Report May 7th, 3:33pm>\nAn unknown challenger has emerged victorious in the arena. He defeated the reigning champion in a mere 12 seconds. An investigation into his identity is underway.

<Report May 7th, 6:08pm>\nA review of the participant roster revealed that the challenger was a foot soldier until yesterday. However, he was using an unfamiliar weapon.\nFurther investigations pending.

<Report May 8th, 11:47am>
The weapon he used was not in our records. Requesting further orders.

<Response May 9th, 9:32am>
We will get back to you in due course.

<Report May 9th, 10:15am>\nWe have destroyed the weapon, stripped the challenger of his title, and prohibited him from participating for three months. We consider the matter closed.\nThank you for your cooperation.
I'd been a slave all my life, the songs of freedom but a dream to me. I couldn't even breathe without permission.
I lived without a single thought of my own. I took orders and did as I was told. Sure, it was tough, but that's just what life is. Or at least that's what I thought.

I couldn't forgive the man who shot Master to set me free. He thought it was the right thing to do. That he was helping me. "Now, you can live how you want to live," he said. It felt like he was mocking how I'd lived up until then.

That's why the first thing I did with my freedom was murder him. The rage welled up inside of me, demanding violence. The next thing I knew, I had taken the gun from Master's pocket and shot my liberator dead.

There once was a man who refused to compromise. Though he had long given up on the military, he still managed to earn a position of command. He didn't bother explaining why to his men. He knew they would never understand.

But he understood better than anybody. The fact that most do not have the will to train, that few opt for anything more than the path of least resistance. That's why he invested everything into his spear. So few, he realized, had the drive to reach his level.

In time, the man's country went to war with its neighbor over their resources. Though crude and inexperienced, his unit proved themselves an able team. But leading such an untrained unit was beneath him. So, he went off on his own.

The man did not fear death. He faced the opposing army alone, inching closer to true mastery with every thrust of his spear. Even a thousand men could not take him. But the enemy troops were as numerous as they were skilled. With no way to reach the archers that rained arrows upon him, the man was slain. The god of war, touched to see him wielding his spear even in the afterlife, imbued the warrior's soul into his beloved weapon. So it was that he could continue to pursue his goal.
♪Ein Männlein steht im Walde ganz still und stumm,\nes hat von lauter Purpur ein Mäntlein um.♪
♪Sagt, wer mag das Männlein sein,\ndas da steht im Wald allein\nmit dem purpurroten Mäntelein.♪
♪Das Männlein steht im Walde auf einem Bein\nund hat auf seinem Kopfe schwarz Käpplein klein...\n♪
...Come on, it's your turn now,\nBrother! ...Dearest? Brother.\nLet me hear you sing!
There once was a boy who lamented being exploited.\nWhen his honest and hard-working parents died due to the carelessness of their feudal lord, he sought to make the world a more just place.

Then one day, a man appeared before the boy and gave him a tome of infinite knowledge. Unable to read a page of it, the boy committed himself to his studies. There was soon not a single word he didn't understand.
But he still had much to learn.\nWhile he could read the tome, he failed to understand it. In time, the boy grew to adulthood, took a wife, and had a family of his own.

It was then that he finally understood the tome.\nHis infinite knowledge plunged him into infinite despair. For he finally understood the truth: No matter how hard they might try, the world would never be just.
They say that laughter's the best medicine.\nIf it really can cure ailments without pills or surgeries or needles, then I'd definitely want to learn to make people laugh.
I tried to learn a few tongue twisters.\nBut when I said them out loud, it just scared the person I told them to. But why?
I tried memorizing a comedy show.\nBut when I tried the routine in public, it just put people to sleep. But why?
"You need to put feeling into it if you want to make someone laugh."\nI took this advice to heart. Sadly, the result was the same.\nI am putting feeling into this! "Laugh already."
Infinitely reflecting mirrors.\nHe dreams. He sees a distant world.
As long as it's not here,\nI'm sure it's somewhere I can shine.
I walk into the mirror.\nI have no idea what lies ahead.
I deny my own incompetence.\nI will until the day I die.\nBecause accepting it would break me...

There once was a pair of identical twin brothers.\nThey were both excellent swordsmen and had bested masters of the craft. But as the two approached adulthood, their father was defeated in a duel, and their family name tarnished.

The older twin stayed loyal to his father's teachings and worked to fight for his country.\nThe younger twin, however, became obsessed with their father's death.\nSearching for the right direction, he decided that brute force would rule the day and set out on a path of inhuman violence.

From then on, both brothers earned renown in the wildly different paths they took. While the older brother fought for his country and earned both status and wealth, the younger took on more unsavory work and was constantly on the run.

In time, the question of who the best swordsman in the kingdom was arose once more, and a duel was scheduled. The older brother won.\n"It is I, the elder brother, who claims victory,"\n he declared, and he was right. He then gave up everything for gold and disappeared into darkness...

[Start]\nTo atone in the slightest bit, I have decided to raise the sole surviving girl and help her once again feel emotions.\nAt first I thought it a lost cause, but I am finally starting to see results. She enjoys life once again, and I occasionally see her almost smile.

[Progress]
I've given up on my promise to her, but she isn't upset.
Seems like she feels that both promises and women are meant to be broken.
I shifted gears today and smashed the hair ornament I originally bought for her.
She had a queer expression on her face, and her anger finally came through.

[Progress]
So much time has passed... We've moved in together.
It's been about ten years since I brought her here.
I searched for that damned hair ornament all over the country and finally found one.
I wonder if she'll forgive me?

[Conclusion]
It's really a shame I can't see you reading this.
I wonder if you feel the loneliness without me by your side.
If you do, that's love. And if seeing my death felt like it
would rip your heart in two, that's sadness.
I sincerely hope I was able to return your human emotions to you.
A beautiful melody melts away on the water's surface.\nAn elegant voice echoes into the sky. It's a beautifully sad echo. It's the song of unrequited love...
The mermaid loved songs from the bottom of her heart.\nWhen that heart was disturbed, she would sing loud, lamenting melodies.
The mermaid was in love.\nBut she knew the love would go unrequited.\nHer singing was, after all, harmful to humans.

How terrible it must be to have a mouth filled with irresponsible emotion.
Her voice would make men go mad.
She was eventually killed at the hands of a man seduced by her song.
In her final moments, the mermaid sang for the warmth of the man she finally managed to touch.
Humans worship and try to overcome beings greater than themselves.\nGod loved them for being so ambitious.
Humans are intelligent. They know to jump into water when they're hot and build a fire when they're cold.\nGod loved them for their resourcefulness.
But even God's favored children were not without their weaknesses.\nGod named their shortcomings the Seven Deadly Sins, and invested much of his time in keeping the humans on the righteous path.

However, this seemed to have the opposite effect.\nTo discourage a human from a course of action only pushes them to do something even more taboo, prompting more people still to follow in their footsteps.\nDevastated by the evil deeds that consumed his children, God decided to flood the world and start anew.

There once was a man who tried to resist the flow of time.
He searched far and wide to find a place that controls time,
 hellbent on reversing 
"time's flow" and reviving his dead wife.
He traveled the world for decades,
but found nothing.
But something within the man's heart changed along the way. He no longer focused on the pain of loss, but instead began to consider the sanctity of her life.

He was ultimately unable to resist the flow of time,
but simultaneously, it was that eternal flow that healed his heart and granted him mercy.
For the first time in decades,
he looked up at the sky and felt contentedness.
"I'm glad to have known you."\nWhispering the words he felt in his heart,\nthe man wept tears of relief and joy.

It wasn't supposed to be this way...\nHe spoke through tears as he thought back on his life.\nAs if in answer, a light flickered alive in a darkened room. It gradually began to take form, and before he knew it, before him stood a fairy like the ones in the tales.

"What do you hold dear?"
The fairy asked.
"List as many things as you want."
It was then that the man reminisced on the path he had traveled.

After several minutes of silence, the man cried and cried, then began to speak of the things that brought him joy. "Sitting down for dinner. Having a job. Being in good health. Spending time with my wife and child..."
But having heard his words, the fairy smiled, ripped away all his happiness, and made despair his sustenance. "Then feed. Feed on everything you hold dear."

There once was a famous gourmand who ate every food he could find in search of perfection. \nBut he was unable to find a dish that satisfied his desire. Over the course of his quest, his diet had become so unhealthy that he eventually lost his sight.

Upon reflecting on the behavior that delivered him to his fate, the old man decided to end his quest for the perfect meal. At the urging of his doctor, he changed his diet and ate healthy meals prepared by his wife.

Realizing that his life was coming to an end,
he found himself dreaming of eating the perfect meal.
It seemed that desire hadn't disappeared after all.
But after years of receiving food from his wife,
the meals suddenly stopped appearing.

Several days passed. After incessant pleading, food finally appeared. It reeked of rot, but the old man was so hungry that he shoveled it into his mouth. The man trembled with euphoria. Finally, he had tasted the perfect meal.

A blind man stood along the road seeking aid in a deserted spot. Something about the beggar caught a passing man's eye, and he stopped to give him a few coins. Grateful, the beggar reached under his cloak and handed the man a beautiful hammer.

"I can't take this," the man said. 
"I wouldn't just give this to anyone," the man insisted, as he handed over the hammer.
The next day the man came back to the same spot
to see the beggar again.

Remembering the price of the hammer, he gave the beggar everything he had on hand.\nThe beggar bowed his head and said, "This time, I give you the most precious thing I have—my soul." With those words, the beggar removed his hood to reveal his face. The man was shocked to behold a knight wanted for the death of the king.

My last insurrection cost me my eyes,
but for you who are pure of heart and has yet to accomplish his dearest desire—
The man, eyes burning with greed, did not wait for the beggar to finish his words.
He beat him to death and collected his bounty.
Things with an end are beautiful.\nLike the noise of festivals and fleeting love.
Things that scatter are beautiful.\nSuch as fireworks at night and petals in the wind.
Things with an end are beautiful.\nThat is the nature of beauty. I didn't understand it when I was up in heaven.\nIt wasn't until I fell to Earth that I really understood.

Things with an end are beautiful.
What humans call a cherry blossom is especially so.
That means that the end of an angel like me will be supremely beautiful.
I put my finger on the trigger.
The girl's fate was decided the moment she entered the world.\nShe knew all along what was in store for her.\nShe knew because she was forced into knowing.
She was strong, but her strength came mainly from her inner resolve.
But, like most, she would eventually lose her way.\nIt happened when a friendly traveler, who lamented her fate, tried to take her away.\nIn that moment the girl was unsure what to do.
She felt weak and conflicted for the first time. \nUnsure of whether or not she would be abandoned, she took matters into her own hands and stabbed him with her spear.

"There are two types of people in this world...
Those who use and those who are used."
That's the only lesson I was taught in the orphanage.
The man I learned it from worked for the government, who used him until there was nothing left.

Before I realized what was happening, I was heading down the path of a user.
I felt no shame in using others as stepping
stones to better my situation in life.
The one tenuous thread holding my conscience together was the sound of a flute I heard back at the orphanage.

As I grew older I hid my lineage to begin working at the royal palace.\nMuch to my surprise, there were many others from my orphanage there.\nIt was then that I realized that the lesson I had learned was right. I continued using people.

It had been ages since I heard that flute.\nA distant memory stirred. I remembered everyone from the orphanage, their eyes unseeing, gathered to kill the king. "I see. So I've been one of the used all this time."\nI had been nothing more than a pawn.
That tome can be used in any way,\nincluding punishing the wicked.
I wrote all of my desires inside to cleanse this world plagued by many evils.\nI started it to pass judgment, plain and simple.

Gradually, I started to add more and more.
"Death to liars."
"Death to those who don't help the weak."
"Death to those who overlook evil deeds."
I became a god and continued passing judgment. I wanted to wash away all evil.\nAnd when it was all finally cleansed, I was the only one left to judge.
Falling sand marks the passage of time.
The winds break against the reef.
Your friend's face pops into your head.
The salt of your tears\nremind you of the sea\nfrom back home.

There was once a princess as beautiful as she was strange,
but no matter how much she searched, she could not find a husband.
She cared not about the social status of a potential husband,
she only wanted him to be buried with her,
even if she died while he still drew breath.

Eventually, a man who sought the princess' hand appeared.
Due to an illness, his days alive were numbered,
so he was unafraid of the princess' request.
But when she succumbed to a disease shortly after their marriage,
the man recalled his promise and trembled in fear of his fate.

Two snakes appeared in the tomb before she was laid to rest.
"I'll protect my wife as long as there is still life in me," he said,
as he cut down one of the snakes. Much to the man's surprise,
the remaining snake placed a flower on the other,
and the dead snake writhed and twitched, filling with life once more.

He placed the flower on his wife's corpse,
but it did not have the same effect.
Instead, he was buried alive with his wife and died shortly after.
But before he slipped into the darkness, he swore he heard a voice call out to him.
"Where am I? Why is it so dark?"
The maiden's thoughts melt into the blade,\nthe steel dyed red from its earnest desires.
The young man murders his beloved maiden. Tears well in his eyes.\nHe holds his blade up to the moon and it reflects his warped smile.
The young man runs away from the taboo. Tears well in his eyes.\nThe blade in his hand reflects the fear as he tries to escape.
Years past and he lost everything.\nHe holds the blade up to the moon and it glimmers in the light.\nThe man feels a weight lift from him as the maiden's wish releases him from its curse.

The grass and flowers were just sprouting when she and the beast first met. The wounded wolf, forsaken from its pack, had lost everything and was prepared to die. As she gazed upon this helpless beast, she sensed it was a kindred spirit, and let it pass even though she was tasked with protecting the village.

After half a year of coexistence, word of other hungry wolves coming into the village began to spread. She tried her best not to let her dear friend know, but it was too perceptive. As suddenly as it appeared, the wolf left the woman's side.

A few nights later, a mournful howl from the mountains pierced through the town.\nShe knew this was her chance to tell the wolf that she, too, did not belong in the town.\nSo she set off to the place they met with the hope of meeting it again.

"Take my corpse back to the village," bellowed the great wolf as it closed its eyes, prepared to take the woman's blow. But she did not move. Realizing the woman was not up to task, it plunged its teeth deep into her throat, inflicting a mortal wound.\nThat night, it was not howling that stirred the village residents, but the tormented wails of the lamenting woman.
My life was designed with purpose.\nAnd without ever truly understanding why I was born,\non the day of my ninth birthday, everything became clear.

"You're simply a spare."
That's what my father said with his cold eyes cast down on me.
In that instant, I knew who I was spare for,
since I had grown up seething with jealousy over how
my parents treated my older sister better.

I began to doubt my father's logic.
Did he really expect me to just accept his
version of the truth, like some dog?
I had known since I was young how my sister's
sickness drove my parents to near insanity.

I wanted to become the real thing,
to seize my own purpose for living.
And since there can only be one,
I had no option but to kill her.
As I approached my languishing sister's bed, she softly smiled as if she had been expecting me...
"Poverty won't beat us. We'll finish this together."\nThough not related by blood, they swore on the relationship as only an older brother and little sister could.
All they had was a single flintlock pistol.\nEven in times of starvation, their pride prevented them\nfrom pawning off their most prized possession.

The pair slowly withered away until they finally collapsed. They had used up all of their strength, and just when it seemed they would keep their promise to each other, they realized the barrel was empty.

Though completely in vain, the older brother held his younger sister close as she pulled back on the trigger.\nIn that instant, the gun, seemingly acknowledging these prideful spirits, exploded with a brilliant light.

Our guild, the "Sacred Beast's Fang," entrusted its members with the task of eradicating many difficult adversaries.\nIt was something my brothers and I took pride in.\nHowever, the dragon we were assigned to kill was like none other. Its jet-black scales shimmered with the flame of its breath.

I looked upon my fallen brothers and in a flash the word "retreat" seared itself into my brain.
It was never this one-sided, so I completely froze.
That same voice was always barking orders at me,
and to this day I regret falling back when I was told to charge.

After returning with my tail between my legs,\nI noticed the lance I had given them standing upright in the burnt soil of the scorched wasteland. It seemed to have been placed there as a memorial of their victory over the dragon.

Overcome with seething vengeance,
I took the lance and used it in many battles.
I hope someday it will allow me to protect my friends. And maybe one day, when she suddenly appears,
she won't find me foolish anymore...

Everyone said they were the nicest couple.
Even when times were rough, they never lost sight of their happiness.
On his beloved wife's birthday,
the man pawned his prized violin
so he could buy her a nice gift.

He prepared a delicious feast and paired it with fine wine. Everything had to be perfect. After all, if he were successful, he'd be rewarded with his wife's beautiful smile. He knew how heavily the inability to bear a child weighed upon her, so even the slightest grin came as a tremendous relief.

Then he waited for her return.
Thinking back on previous nights, he recalled her arriving home later than usual.
Before going to bed the night before, he noticed how exhausted she looked.
Still, she smiled at him as always and said, "What am I going to do with you?"
Considering that, he wasn't too worried with her lateness, but still...

Maybe something happened? The man couldn't bear to stand around any longer and set out to find his wife. He had only just grabbed his coat when he heard her speak.\n"What am I going to do with you?" He stood there, dumbfounded, looking at his love, who clutched his violin in her hands. In that moment, he realized why she had been coming home so late.
The only way to realize dreams in this insane world was through sleep. No wish was unattainable within a sweet, sweet dream.

Knowing that, it's plain to see why a tome that could control dreams would be so sought after.\nUpon finally obtaining it, a mage set out to reprint the tome so that everyone in the world could attain true happiness.
If we are to point out the difference\nbetween dying and continuing to sleep,\nit's whether or not it can be interrupted.

Before long, the mage's wish was granted, and reprints of the tome were distributed across the land.\nBoth the sane and the mad migrated to the world of dreams, and so it too became a world of insanity.\nIn the end, the only one spared this tragedy was the dead mage himself.

The owner of the cane was a delightful person who healed anyone who needed it.\nAs a priest, it was part of their duty to travel from village to village healing the needy. One day, however, the priest came upon a town engulfed in a fog of despair.

The priest asked one of the villagers what had happened. They responded that following a poor harvest, their lord had begun to demand sacrifices. The incredulous priest explained that such a thing would not help their harvests, and so they proceeded to dig up the buried sacrifices.

The priest began to heal the fallen. When they awoke, however, they greeted the priest not as a savior, but as a tormentor.
"Demon! Our families will starve to death
now that you've meddled with the ritual!"
They showered the gentle priest with insults as they beat him to death.

A long time passed, and eventually the people came to understand that their sacrifices would not bring change.\nKnowing this, their opinion of the "demonic" priest changed instantly. He came to be revered as a saint, and his staff is now a holy object.

There once was an unsuccessful bard.\nThe words to his songs were ill chosen, and even the nicest of folk tried to get him to stop crooning. However, unbeknownst to all, the bard crafted a masterpiece that the world had never known.
The song was gifted to him after he saved a fairy.\n"This song holds within it tremendous power, my dear. You must only sing it in times of dire need," said the fairy.
The bard continued with his writing.\nHowever, life was not kind to him. Several times he considered sharing his masterpiece with the world,\nbut instead he opted to keep his promise to the fairy.

The bard pressed on, slowly withering away from starvation until he was just moments from death. With his dying breath, he sang the fairy's song.\nIn that instant, his body was enveloped in light,\nand in that moment was transformed into a fairy who knew nothing of hunger.
Rain washes the tears from my face.\nI wish it would wash me away, too.\nWhat a ridiculous thought... But I'd expect nothing less from myself moments before I'm offered to the heavens as a sacrifice.

I knew it would come down to this.\nEspecially when everyone looked at me when the rain stopped falling. They claimed this was the reason I was born, but not one of them could hide the indifference in their eyes.
Each word they uttered pushed me closer and closer to the edge of the cliff.\nThe meaning behind each word was kind,\nthough each one beckoned my death.

The roiling waves crashed below, calling me to rest under their cold embrace. I held the sword, passed down from generation to generation, against my chest and was swallowed up by the great blue. Among the countless bodies below, a blue light enveloped the sword as it quietly swayed.

The woman had feelings for someone.
It was the king who had defeated the corrupt nobles, the man who brought peace to her home.
"I will support him no matter what happens."
Her resolve held strong as she left the town.

Pretending to be something she wasn't, she became the subordinate her superiors wanted.\nShe deceived all around her and moved up in the world.\nAfter many years of this, she was finally granted an audience with the king. Unfortunately, he had succumbed to illness and could no longer grant her one.

But she realized that she was not upset.
Being someone she was not to achieve her goal meant she had lost herself in the process.
When he finally died, she was at his side, smiling.
While she wept on the inside, she found herself unable to break the smile she used to flatter her superiors.

No matter how much she regretted it, her old self was never coming back.\nEverything slowed down the moment she realized that.\nThe only thing that didn't change was the hammer she continued to wield in battle.

I have no family, no friends, no past.
I just found myself unbelievably hungry and started wandering around town.
I was really, REALLY hungry. Imperial forces saved me.
In some sense, it might have been inevitable that I learn the meaning of life there.
Before I knew it, I was surrounded by others faced with similar circumstances.\nWe were called wanderers, and our livelihoods were secured in exchange for protecting a faceless benefactor.
"Strive to be the best. If you do, I promise you greater happiness."\nTrusting those words, I continued to wield my sword in battle.\nActually... It was beyond mere trust. Those words became my life.

Eventually, my benefactor appeared before me and held out his hand.\n"Congratulations. You are now a knight in the Imperial Order. From now on, you will not only serve me, but the Empire as well."\nWith those words, he gave me the spear that would become a symbol of the belief that had sustained me.
When the man was told of the power the flute possessed, he had his doubts. But he realized the truth of it from the first note he played, when all the townsfolk who heard stopped in silence.
Play it once, and time stops. Play it again, and the flow of time begins again. With that kind of power in his possession, there was much the man hoped to achieve.

From then on, he played the flute often and got many of the things he desired.
He used it to marry a woman so beautiful,
she'd make anyone envious.
He used it to get some of the world's most valuable treasures.
But he became so dependent on its power that he couldn't hide the evil deeds he had done.

Another day, another round of evil deeds.
He was calm when the guards caught up with him.
He tried to stop time, and the flute's notes whistled through the air.
The flute broke and the man, no longer able to stop time, was finally arrested.
fo0005_1.10.1\nWithout Yggdrasil, the world's life would die off and eventually be extinguished altogether.\nI've entrusted my research data to my son, and the future of the planet with it.

fo0005_1.10.2
This is terrible. The planet appears to be restoring itself.
It seems that the Yggdrasil's future death is all but guaranteed.
Our efforts to change the course of history have been in vain.
fo0005_1.10.3\nI have good news.\nIt appears that if we change history in a way that doesn't impact life on the planet, the planet will overlook that change.

fo0005_1.10.4
A meteorite from outer space has given us the gift called "magic."
With its help, we might just be able to save humanity.
The fact that this planet is doomed remains unchanged, however.
The judge had not a smidgen of warmth in his heart.\nHe received pleasure in life by passing judgment on criminals.

One day, he handed down judgment on the eldest of many brothers.\nHe was seen breaking and entering, and caused bodily harm while resisting arrest.\nThe younger brothers' long struggle finally ended when they died while waiting for their older brother to return.

The brother was in tears. "I'll do anything. Just let me go, please! I have ten brothers at home who are starving to death as we speak."
"Then kill one of them," the judge replied.
"That's better than all of them dying, isn't it?"
The judge viewed his sentence as merciful.

The next day, when the brother returned with the head of the ninth brother, the judge charged him with murder. His intention from the start was to execute the boy. His sentence hadn't contained the slightest semblance of mercy after all.
I don't have any special powers, and yet,\nI've found a way to make a fortune.
Rumors of me are spreading far and wide.\nThey say my fortune-telling is never wrong.\nSure, it took some money to get those rumors going, but I'll get it back.
The day of my audience with the king nears.\nMy plan is nearing its final stage.\nIf I get the results I want, I'll announce them.

The day I'm telling the king's fortune has finally arrived.
I've practiced the fortune I intend to give countless times.
"Wait for the day. An angry mob will come."
I slowly smile, certain of the accuracy of my prediction.
Words didn't work with those men.
The only conversations they had were with swords.
They understood each other's feelings.\nLooking at each other's countries, they knew they could never coexist.
So they thrust their blades into each other's chest\nand swore to live together in the afterlife.
There was once a cool-headed soldier in a prosperous empire. He never failed a mission, his proudest accomplishment.
He was also as skilled in politics as he was on the field of battle. None could claim themselves his equal.

That is, until the man first experienced failure.\nOne of his subordinates had killed an innocent man.\nIf it had been an inconsequential mistake, the man would not have minded, but for him, this was an unforgivable mishap.

This man, in his infinite wisdom, decided it would be better to protect his flawless record by hiding the incident quickly. And so, he proceeded with the burial...\nOf every single witness, that is.\nThose who saw this purge suffered the same fate, and so on, and so forth...
While there are many renowned magical blades in the world, there is also anecdotal evidence of the existence of cursed guns.\nThis is a story about one such gun.
There was a gun sealed away with the words "DO NOT TOUCH."\nNearby, there was a struggling town with infertile farmlands, and nearly nothing to produce or keep its villagers fed and comfortable.

The town's mayor, overcome by a strong sense of justice,\ndecided she'd take the gun to protect the town from bandits, who ravaged the town and abducted children. But a single shot from her beloved gun would end up destroying a village.

The truth of the gun's curse is that it would steal happiness and joy.
If she'd just obeyed the rules, none of this would have ever happened.
If they'd just handed over their valuables, the lives of both robbers and townsfolk could have been spared.
But her sense of justice... Ended up being the emotion that destroyed the village.
The noise of the tavern drowns out the screaming of my heart. The stink of the alcohol in the air assaults my nose.\n"I've failed again."
This always happens.\nI share my feelings, and the other person views it as an annoyance. They start talking through their teeth. Flimsy lies. I'm starting to not believe them anymore.
When I've had some drinks, I can tell when men are lying to me. I take joy in taking men into extreme situations to find out who they really are.

A man apologized for tricking me yet again today.\nI cannot wait to spin my web at the tavern, to see if I can find a man who points his blade in my direction and declares to the world how much he loves me...

The men took great pride in their work as vigilantes in a town on the decline. They protected it from monsters, made it a place where the townsfolk could sleep comfortably at night, and left them feeling a sense of importance.
And then a hero appeared and brought peace to the town. The townsfolk—who were once grateful to the vigilantes—found their respect all but vanished, and turned their admiration to the hero overnight.

The vigilantes couldn't believe what happened.\nThey couldn't accept that they were no longer appreciated after all they'd done for the village.\nThey hated the new hero. And so to take him down, they decided to play the part of criminals in the dead of night.

If the town was threatened once again, the townsfolk would surely seek their help again.
Or at least, that was their thinking... Although it pained them to do so, they made the town's food storage the target of their attack.
But they did not expect the townsfolk to be waiting for them there.
They hadn't forgotten their efforts and were still grateful for all they had done.
Ever since the "massive, ominous jewel" was excavated from the mine,\npeople have been inflicted with a strange illness.\nIt's extremely fatal, and there seems to be no cure.
The illness spread across the land over several months and took the lives of many workers. Those who survived fought over resources and dismissed the tragedy as a natural phenomenon.
The sound of a violin floated over the conflict.\nThose who heard its sweet song are said to have stopped fighting.
Dissonance destroys a person's heart.\nThe musician played as he walked amongst the corpses. The violin and its \n"massive jewel" amplified said dissonance.

Observation Notes
Subject: 6 y.o. / Male / Unemployed
Desire: Toys
Result: Fulfilled, but he grew tired of them several days later

Observation Notes
Subject: 32 y.o. / Male / Logistics Worker
Desire: Wealth
Result: Ends up in tremendous debt with desire fulfilled

Observation Record
Subject: 29 y.o. / Female / Maid
Desire: To be exploited
Result: All candidates failed her tests
―――――――Impressions―――――――\nDoes not compute. More subjects needed.\nContinue observation.
The old man with the miraculous staff finally gave in.\n"I want to save my mom," the boy yelled over and over. The old man responded to such foolishness by revealing the truth about the staff.

He regretted the lies he told, the deceptions of a a sick old man with too much money on his hands, and told the boy the true nature of the staff.\n"This staff is just a useless old piece of wood...but this might be of help to you," he said, handing him money.

The boy used the money to hire a noted physician.
And just as the boy had hoped, his mother recovered from her illness.
Unfortunately, the same doctor was unable to help the old man who had given the boy money.
He came down with an unknown illness, claiming he was beyond help.
To reward his benefactor, the boy set out on a journey to find healing powers strong enough to make the staff real.

In time, the boy returned to the old man with a great power.
"I can't believe it," the old man cried.
"You made the staff's power real!"
It was then that the boy told him the truth: that this power, too, was a lie, one meant to make the old man feel better for his good deed.

Welcome, traveler. This is your lucky day.\nTonight's the night that everybody forgets everything and dances the night away. It's the day our country celebrates the god of the harvest.\nA nationwide celebration is already underway.

This is a lantern of hope.\nWe take lanterns of various shapes and sizes and fill the town with god's light. Alright, then. Take this lantern and walk around town. It's free of charge. In fact, all of the shops will be offering food for free tonight.

By the way, you don't have a partner by chance, do you? Oh my, what a shame! Then call out to any women holding blue lanterns if you see them. Do that for several hours, and you've got a shot at finding a future spouse.

The revelry continued, and the man's belly was stuffed with all of the food he'd received. The traveler completely forgot that he originally came there to steal.\nHe even found love and a job! This is the lantern he carried that day.

I knew it would come to this.
I've just been avoiding him, delaying the inevitable.
But that's over now. I abandoned all hope of reconciliation and began to tell him the truth...
This was scarier than anything else.
That's right. You should absolutely detest me.

"You... You took from me the person I loved most!"
He drew his sword. I really wanted him to kill me.
But I couldn't die until I revealed the feelings I'd been hiding.
If I set one foot wrong, the response will be his knife. I tread carefully as I began to explain.

"I'm glad I can finally die, but I had no choice in the matter..."
"Why?! Why did you hide the truth and befriend me!
I... I thought we were friends!" His words were a relief, his swordsmanship heavy-handed and easy-to-read,
so I feigned feebleness to accept the blow.

The sword pierced my chest. A pool of blood.
The smell of iron.
I speak of my death.
It wasn't exactly where I wanted to die, but I was glad to be embraced by him, no matter the circumstances.
I have no right to have feelings like these.
Still, I felt...at peace.
The man seemed extremely ordinary.\nHe always did his job to the best of his ability, but work was not his purpose in life.
The man seemed to have a hobby.\nBut unfortunately, the man was forced to give up much of his free time for work,\nbut he accepted it for what it was.
The man seemed to have a lover.\nThough he lacked the glimmer in his eyes that betokens a man in love.
Out of curiosity, I went to his house to ask about his life's purpose. In a dark room, he answered my question in a way I didn't expect.\n"MY PURPOSE? IT'S...\nTO KILL EVERYONE WHO LOOKS DOWN ON ME!"

The girl's father was an accomplished archer who, after several brushes with his demise, was said to have befriended the death god. They were so close, in fact, that the death god became the girl's godparent.
This allowed her to stop death, a power she used to make a living as a doctor. One day, she revealed her unusual ability to a friend, who offered a business proposition.

She soon began masquerading as a prophet who could predict when a person would die. It wasn't long before word of her powers reached the ears of the wealthy, who were eager to reward her prognostications with huge sums of money. It was a fine plan...or would have been, if only the death god allowed it.

It wasn't long before death stood at her bedside, scythe raised as if to strike her down. But the woman was unafraid. She leapt to her feet, pulling one of her father's old bows from the wall and firing upon the death god, watching as the flight of the arrow perfectly coincided with the clock above death's head counting rapidly to zero.

One day, a young man went to the woods on a hunt and encountered a dwarf with a spear strong enough to pierce solid rock.\n"Where did you get that?" the man found himself asking. The dwarf's response came in the form of song.\n"The youngest of seven brothers made it."

The man felt his heart well up with desire for the spear.\nHe asked politely for the dwarf to craft one, and much to his surprise, he readily agreed. But humans and dwarves have different values.\nThe one condition was that the young man must explain in great detail what he wanted to have made.

The man explained as best he could what he wanted the spear to look like.\n"It should be three-times the length of my outstretched hands. It should weigh less than 40 pounds. It should have a wavy ornament attached to the spearhead..."\nHis explanation took several days, but the dwarf promised to craft it quickly and come to him when it was done.

The man went on with his life, but the spear never came.\nWhen at long last it did, the house had long been deserted. The man's request was too detailed, and it took nearly a century in human years to craft.

Command Diary, October 4th (Sunny)
"That was too cruel, wasn't it? My staff..."
Today's command was to take the money my grandfather
worked so hard to save and gamble it away.

"This is no place for children. Leave."
The man glared at me menacingly.
But when I showed him a wad of bills, he seemed satisfied and gave me a command.
"Trust me on this. Bet it all at once."

I felt a chill run down my spine.\nI mean, if I lost the bet, my grandfather would let me have it like never before. Then he'd give me more commands than I'd know what to do with.\n"Why give me such a horrible command... My staff..."

*Sigh*... It was automatic.
Having won the bet, I talked to my staff. Hey, give me another command already.
Out with it. Out with it. Out with it already...
I can't have them if you don't command me.
These exhilarating experiences...
Magic that resurrects the dead.\nMaster that, and I'm sure to find a gentleman who will tend to me. After all, there are more dead men underground than living men above it.
At first, I resurrected the dead who had secrets,\nbut I couldn't find a single one who would attack or torment me.

But I was sure to eventually succeed if I tried enough. Trusting this logic, I went to the graveyard and resurrected some of the dead there.\nOnce more, I couldn't find a man for me. So then I figured...why don't I resurrect them all?

But I failed. The skeletal body was simply too light. I put armor on it, but it lacked any and all skill. I spent many years training my man, but I was too desperate to make it work and before I knew it, I was too old for any of it to matter.
The name of that prison would send shivers down the spine of even the most hardened criminal.\nNo one has ever escaped with their lives, and over time, monstrous rumors have sprung up surrounding it.

All who serve time there are shackled by the neck.\nSeveral inmates have succumbed to the manacle's curse. No amount of rumors trickling out about this terrible place can save those stuck inside. Though countless thieves have met in the dark of night to exchange methods of breaking the curse, no one ever makes it out alive.
Professional criminals aren't the only ones held in that prison—guilty townsfolk are incarcerated there, too. Their only recourse, their only means of escape, is often relayed in hushed whispers.

The shackles respond to pleas of "free me" by separating the inmate's head from their body. That severed head will say the accursed words yet again, and inmates who overhear repeat them out of blind desperation. Only prisoners who keep their wits about them make it to the end of their sentence.
This is the key room.\nThere are no sounds or desires, only beasts that eat the grass.
This is the corpse room.\nHere, sacrifices are invited to live with no knowledge of their impending demise.
This is the bearing room.\nWhere those who seek serenity from turbulent times seek refuge.
A master, longing for eternal silence, sought a spear that could pierce through anything.\n"Are you sure you want me? Can you truly bear all this hatred?"

The axe was always watching. It wanted to help the little boy. He would return from his daily scolding, exhausted. Only in sleep could he escape his troubles. The axe appeared to him in his dreams and asked,\n"Don't you want to get away from this life?"

The boy desperately tried to ignore the dream, but the axe had gotten inside his head. No matter how they wounded him, the boy remembered how his parents had taken him in. How they had saved his life.
The next morning, the boy woke to earsplitting wails.\nHis right hand felt heavy. When he looked down, he saw the axe from his dreams, drenched in blood.

The axe had seen the truth,
and so it carried out the boy's true wish.
If you can see into someone's mind,
knowing their heart is no trouble at all.
There once was a knight, braver and stronger than anyone.
Though he was trusting of those around him, the knight was also unlucky.
The knight served a country perpetually at war,\nand had been sent into danger countless times.
Still the knight would rush in, leading a bold charge head on. And today, once again, he led his men to their deaths, and made his triumphant return alone.
The man wept as if he laughed, and smiled as though he cried. All who saw the man called him a freak. An abomination. But he loved humans and wanted to make them all smile.
He wore heavy makeup and hid his identity.\nWhen the man became a clown, he stole the show.\nThe audience was enthralled, laughing with such force it was hard to breathe.

His show took pains to prepare.
"Ahah! Ahah hah hah!"
His laughter would fill the air again tonight...
He got ready, always smiling as though crying.

To prepare for his show, he needed a sickle that could manipulate the emotions of precisely the number of people it killed. For his greatest show, he cut down half the world, and by doing so, achieved his dream. His warped face wept as if he laughed.

The honest demon had not forgotten the nun who rescued him when he teetered on the verge of death. Once he'd recovered, he gave her many gifts in return.\nHowever, he made a decision to spread rumors about why he was visiting her for his own sake.

The rumors claimed that the nun invited him.
But demons are hated by humans.
A fact that this particular demon could not comprehend.
Of course, her love was unable to reach him.

There were rumors of a nun who was in love with a demon, making her the most desperate of star-crossed lovers. She had become smitten by the sight of his black wings. Though the thought of him was all consuming, her love went unrequited.

"Play this instrument to let me know when you're about to die."
That was the last letter the demon left her.
Time passed, and the nun was on her deathbed.
Before an angel could visit, she played the demon flute as promised and was delivered to hell.

There was once a country populated by the elderly alone, and its final king was an old woman in secret. This story is about when she was still young and beautiful. She was very bright, and when the votes were collected from the citizens, she was named the country's king.

The woman's reign was long, and when she finally grew old, she crafted all of the nation's policies in service of the elderly. It was for this reason that the country began to decline, prompting its youngest residents to move elsewhere.

Having ruled over the country's downfall, the woman had earned the animosity of all its citizens.
"It wasn't supposed to end like this," she wept in an uncontrollable fit of madness.
Her people took pity on her and spared her life,
but the old queen was exiled from the country.

The woman was smart and anticipated this.
Her madness was nothing but a ruse!
With the money she'd leeched from her subjects,
she lived the rest of her days in peace, surrounded by a number of handsome young companions.

There once was a weapon that would unleash its user's magical abilities while also amplifying certain emotions. It was called the Apprentice Staff. The reason for the name is a simple one—all of its owners had died while still engaged in apprenticeship.

There came a girl who sought the staff despite knowing its history. She needed its power. Her parents had faced a demon and, finding their power lacking, were both slain. The girl wanted revenge against the creature above all else, and so she looked for the staff.

The emotion the staff amplified for her was arrogance.
The girl became prone to showing off.
Her fellow students resented her, but she used their envy to earn a reputation.
Before long, the demon appeared before her.
With a dazzling display of magic, revenge was finally hers.

A student stood before the exhausted girl. "I hope you feel better now." The students used recovery magic on her, but the arrogant girl had little interest in the actions of others.\nShe did not know they'd used such magic. She would never know that the students had lost one of their own to the demon.

There was once a village that would only allow the pure of heart to take up residence. They all followed their religious leader without question, and rumors of their plight eventually reached a holy king. He believed it was up to him to save the people.

A furious battle ensued. It took the holy king a long while to secure victory. He enacted a plan to save those who had been enslaved by the false religion.\nThe king decreed that anyone who disobeyed the commandments of the holy city must repent at the gate on the summit.

Having suppressed the village, the holy king returned to the city triumphant. The imprisoned leader caught wind of this and pushed the villagers to revolt in a bid to regain control.\n"Kill the heretics!" Many joined the rebel army in response to these anguished cries, and they reclaimed their village in a single night.

Following the battle, the villagers gathered at the gate.
The religious leader forced his way inside.
The holy king stood before him laughing.
